I noticed 2 things here. 

First, `filePath` is essentially `"./" + folderName + "/" + fileName` making it redundant since you can just do the operation when required. I suggest creating a helper function `makeFilePath(String folderName, String fileName)` to do so and reuse the function for better code reusability and makes it cleaner too. 
 
Second, I see that you do not have an overloaded constructor utilising one or more of `folderName`, `fileName` and `filePath` which makes them a constant. In that case, you might consider converting to `static final` and using `UPPER_SNAKE` case variable names, ie. 
```java
private static final String FOLDER_NAME = "data";
private static final String FILE_NAME = "elysia.txt";
private static final String FILE_PATH = "./data/elysia.txt";
```
 Though I understand that you might be considering adding an overload constructor like
```java
public Elysia(String fileName) ``{``
    // code
``}``
``` 
then in that case I think it is ok to leave `fileName` and but personally, I will still convert `folderName` to `private static final String FOLDER_NAME` 
</panel>

Third part or both second and third parts can be omitted depending on what's covered in the test. Generally it's not a good idea to not push data files like this to a remote repository. Otherwise if you had actual tasks saved to the file, strangers like me can see your *potentially private* data :O

You can consider adding the following to the `.gitignore` file in your root directory:

```bash
# current content of .gitignore
# ...
/data/
```

So that when you add files to a git commit, git knows to ignore the directory `./data/` :D

- Avoid unnecessary use of this with fields. Use the `this` keyword only when a field is shadowed by a method or constructor parameter.

<div slot="header">

**11 :fas-comment:**
</div>

The method name `prettyText` might not be the best way to name this static method.

1. Although the word 'pretty' can be used as a verb, it may not be the most intuitive interpretation of the word ('pretty' can be an adjective to describe the word 'text' as well).
2. Moreover, the method name also may not be most descriptive in telling readers what the function does, which is to add a leading space to every line in the string.

Perhaps you can consider renaming the method to
- `convertToPrettyText()` (method name that starts with a verb) or
- `toPrettyText()` (similar to the `toString()` method name)

to address issue 1, or you could consider something even more descriptive (and possibly overkill), such as:
- `addLeadingSpaceToText()` (very explicit in terms of what the method does)

to address issue 2.

This ultimately boils down to personal preference, but these would be my suggestions. :)
</panel>

The switch statement should have the following form: Note there is no indentation for case clauses.

```java
switch (condition) ``{``
case ABC:
    statements;
    // Fallthrough
case DEF:
    statements;
    break;
case XYZ:
    statements;
    break;
default:
    statements;
    break;
``}`` 
```
</panel>

Maybe writing descriptive header comments for all public classes/methods could improve the readability of the code?
The following suggestions are extracted from [here](https://se-education.org/guides/conventions/java/intermediate.html)
You MUST write header comments for all classes, public methods. But they can be omitted for the following cases:
- Getters/setters
- When overriding methods (provided the parent method's Javadoc applies exactly as is to the overridden method)
</panel>

To add on to liauzhanyi, maybe to help remedy the issue of wildcard imports, and assuming you are using IntelliJ as your IDE, you can:

`Go to settings -&gt; Editor -&gt; Code style -&gt; Java -&gt; Imports`

And under the "Class count to use import with *" field, you can change the number to 10000 or any large number.
You can also change the "Names count to use static import with *" for static imports.
This will ensure that IntelliJ will not classify your imports from the same package into a wildcard import (Unless you have more than 10000 imports ü§£)

**1 :fas-comment:**
</div>

Missing Hi/Hello Command

It looks like the application might be missing a response for a `hi` or `hello` command. Since users might naturally start an interaction with a greeting, adding this command could improve user experience. For instance, a simple response like "Hi there! How can I assist you today?" would be great.
</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2425S1/ip/pull/237#discussion_r1741626021" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**2 :fas-comment:**
</div>

I noticed that the current implementation allows the creation of events with invalid dates, such as when the 'to' date is earlier than the 'from' date. For example:

``` 
event meeting /from 2022-12-12 /to 2021-12-12
Got it. I've added this task: 
    [E][ ] meeting (from: 12 Dec 2022 to: 12 Dec 2021) 
Now you have 5 tasks in the list. 

Saving data...
Save successful.
```

This could lead to confusion and potentially incorrect data being stored. I suggest adding validation to check that the 'to' date is not earlier than the 'from' date before allowing the task to be created.

</panel>
